column1: 06_Fourier Series.tex@$$y''+4y =t  \;
column2: \; \; y(0)=y(2)=0$$@Note: The conditions $y(0)=0$ and $y(2)=0$ are endpoint value conditions
column3: and the differential equation $y''+4y =t$ is thought to hold for $0<t<2$ (i.e. in between the endpoints 0 and 2). The goal is to find a continuous function that satisfies both the differential equation and the endpoint conditions. Although this can be solved using the usual method of undetermined coefficients
column4: let us learn how to find the solution using Fourier series. (The advantage of Fourier series solution is that the right side
column6: could be replaced by any piecewise continuous function and we can still solve it.)\n\nSolution) Notice that the trigonometric functions that satisfy $y(0)=0$ and $y(2)=0$ are $\sin$ functions of certain period. More specifically
column7: $\sin \frac{2n\pi}{2} t $ satisfies the requirement. The idea of the solution is to put $y$ as sum of these functions
column8:
i.e.
$$y = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} c_n \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t$$
Then it will automatically satisfy the endpoint value conditions. Let us differentiate in order to plug this into the differential equation.
$$y'' = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} - rac{n^2\pi^2}{4} c_n \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t$$

Plugging in
column9:
we have:
$$y''+ 4y = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} - rac{n^2\pi^2}{4} c_n \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t + 4\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}  c_n \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t $$
$$ = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left(- rac{n^2\pi^2}{4}+4 ight) c_n \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t $$

Now this has to be matched with the right side
column10: which is $t$. But when you set them equal
column11: the conclusion is not clear:\n$$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left(-\frac{n^2\pi^2}{4}+4 \right) c_n \sin \frac{2n\pi}{2} t =t$$\nIn other words
column12:
we can't figure out what $c_n$ should be. Thus we take the Fourier sine series of $t$.
$$ t = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t$$
where
$$b_n =  rac{2}{2} \int_0^2 t \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t = \left(  rac{-2}{n\pi} t \cos  rac{2n\pi}{2} t +  rac{4}{n^2\pi^2} \sin   rac{n\pi}{2} t ight) \Bigg\vert_0^2 $$
$$ = - rac{4}{n\pi} (-1)^n$$
So we have:
$$ t = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} - rac{4}{n\pi} (-1)^n \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t$$
Now
column14:
we can compare the coefficients to deduce the following:
$$\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \left(- rac{n^2\pi^2}{4}+4 ight) c_n \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t =\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} - rac{4}{n\pi} (-1)^n \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t$$
$$\left(- rac{n^2\pi^2}{4}+4 ight) c_n = - rac{4}{n\pi} (-1)^n$$
Solving this for $c_n$ gives us:
$$c_n =  rac{- rac{4}{n\pi} (-1)^n}{- rac{n^2\pi^2}{4}+4} $$

Plugging this back into $y$ gives us the answer:
$$y = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}  rac{- rac{4}{n\pi} (-1)^n}{- rac{n^2\pi^2}{4}+4} \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t$$@y = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}  rac{- rac{4}{n\pi} (-1)^n}{- rac{n^2\pi^2}{4}+4} \sin  rac{2n\pi}{2} t

 egin{itemize}
